awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Study of the Impact of Pre-Service Teacher Research Experience on Effectiveness, Persistence, and Retention
awd_abstract_narration:
Authentic research opportunities for prospective K-12 science and mathematics teachers within their pre-service education program is a relatively recent STEM education element. This Track 4 Noyce Research study will investigate how this approach impacts teacher effectiveness, persistence, and retention. The project will compare a cohort of teachers who participated in STEM research as part of their teacher training (teacher-researchers) with a comparison group of teachers who have been similarly prepared but have limited research backgrounds. Approximately half of the teacher-researchers involved in this study were also Noyce Scholars, who have committed to teaching in high-need settings. The findings of this study may lead to improved STEM education and educator development by demonstrating the impacts of research experiences for pre-service teachers. Findings will also inform research partnerships involving academia, industry, and federal agencies. Finally, the ultimate measure of any teacher research experience is the impact on the students of the teacher-researcher. This study will examine the extent to which teacher-researchers effectively engage their students in science, engineering, and mathematical practices and prepare their students for STEM careers. 

The treatment group in this quasi-experimental, comparative study will involve 303 individuals (including 175 Noyce Scholars) who participated for one to three years in a pre-service teacher-researcher program in partnerships with national research laboratories from 2010-2014. This group will be compared with Noyce Scholars and other teacher candidates who applied to but did not participate in research. The project will also focus on a subset of 159 treatment-group participants (including 51 Noyce Scholars) from four higher education institutions. This subsample will be compared with other Noyce Scholars and teacher candidates prepared by the same institutions, but with limited research experience. To measure impacts on persistence and retention, the study will investigate career trajectories of the treatment and comparison groups. Informed by this work, the project will conduct additional data collection in four high-need local educational agencies with high numbers of treatment group participants to identify matched comparison teachers within their schools. Additional data collected from these selected districts will include teacher and principal/supervisor interviews along with K-12 student surveys and data from student achievement assessments aligned with state standards. Controlling for academic and demographic variables, teacher preparation, and local school and district characteristics, the study will inform how teacher effectiveness, retention, and persistence are impacted by enrichment of the Noyce Scholar experience through summer research. This study has strong potential to broadly and significantly contribute to both policy and practice associated with STEM teacher preparation, specifically with regards to providing STEM research opportunities for future STEM teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The STEM Teacher and Researcher (STAR) Program provides future and early career K-12 STEM teachers with paid STEM summer research experiences at national research laboratories and university campuses. STAR Fellows experience cutting-edge scientific research firsthand and are supported to translate that experience into lesson plans that can have a transformative impact on their future students’ learning and engagement in STEM. Existing research illustrates positive impacts of the STAR Program as reported by participants completing the summer research experience. The purpose of this project is to determine longer-term impacts of the STAR program for previous Fellows who are now full-time high school STEM teachers. In particular, the goals of this research project are to compare the impacts of the STAR program on teacher persistence and retention and on achievement of students who are taught by STAR Fellows.

This collaborative research was conducted across several institutions including Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, San Francisco State University, California State University Sacramento (Sacramento State), and Fresno State University. In total, 16 California teachers (8 STAR Fellows and an equal number of matched comparison teachers) and 1,132 students across seven school districts were included in this research, with analysis being supported by the American Institute of Research and the University of Arizona.

Findings demonstrate similar math and science achievement scores on standardized tests for high-school students when comparing students who had STAR and non-STAR teachers, regardless of whether the students attended high-need schools. Compared with students of non-STAR teachers, students of STAR teachers report statistically significant more positive perceptions in STEM career awareness, the value of learning STEM subjects, and perseverance in STEM subjects. Interviews with STAR and matched comparison non-STAR teachers illustrate that teachers with STEM research experiences are more likely to talk about STEM careers and to discuss careers in different ways, drawing on their own experiences, and are more likely to talk about science and engineering practices called for in current science standards. Analysis of district level teacher employment data indicates stronger retention in high need schools after six years among both STAR Fellows and STAR Applicants (individuals who applied to but did not participate in the teacher research experience) in comparison to teachers who never applied to or participated in the program. Findings are being shared through both a AAAS book chapter and peer-reviewed publications.

Research on the impact of summer research experiences for teachers in terms of their future students’ learning and engagement in STEM is in its infancy, with this study being the first of its kind in California. This project provides a possible guide for other researchers attempting to collaborate across institutions to determine the longer-term outcomes of STEM research on K-12 teaching and student achievement. Given that future and practicing teachers, in many cases, have had limited opportunities to experience science firsthand in laboratories, these findings provide important evidence about the value of summer STEM research experiences for teachers. Such experiences inform teachers of entry points and careers in STEM that they can integrate into their classroom activities for enhanced student engagement in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: John M Keller
